TopicTitle: The thread for all things Curiosity related

Articles.Content:
0.00456m/s horizontal velocity. New Kerbal challenge, try to beat that!

Yeah, with a whole kilogram of fuel to spare as well!

Landed like a boss...

Picture is here folks.

Whered you get that info Alvarien? I have been looking for that for the past 10 minutes. The stream I was watching cut the mission control sound out just as they were saying it..

I had thought they were saying 2.27 miles.

Either way, 250m or 2 miles, its incredibly close.

You can see curiosities wheel
WOO! Good job to them all
Awesome landing. Takes me ages to kill horizontal velocity. I'm usually left hovering for a good minute. But it was like bam.

I heard 250 meters, but even if it is 2 miles, it is AWSOME !!!

I was watching the french stream and they said that before the atmospheric entrance, when the cruise stage decoupled. They said exactely 232 meters.

Edited August 6, 2012 by Alavarien-46

They said ~220 meters so, yes, less than 250m.

A great achievement. Well done NASA and to all those that worked on the project.

It's a good thing Kerbals didn't design that mission ...

Man, I'm freaking out about getting to new planets (when they come) in KSP... Heck how the hell am I supposed to get back?!? Yet alone land something and return it...

I'm still amazed they landed 900kg of raw awesome on Mars.

Edited August 6, 2012 by hebdomad
Ok tog, I must have extrapolated wrong. My feed said something like "227" then the commentator cut in. I assumed it was finishing with 2.27 miles, must have been 227m. That is incredible.

Yeah, with a whole kilogram of fuel to spare as well!

The extra kilogram is what makes it rocket science
Well done NASA, now lets it if she brings back any useful information!

Well done NASA, now lets it if she brings back any useful information!

It absolutely will, not necessarily immediately applicable but it'll be a gold mine.
Congrats and good job to everyone involved. I think I'll make my avatar the mars thumbnail image
I certainly hope so
Next step, send men to Mars !!! (and get them back, of course !)
The whole time Curiosity was tracking, I was working on my Minmus landing (in realtime.)

I heard they had to use MechJeb to land it properly

Seriously, though, this is amazing.

This is, in my opinion, the most important step in our exploration of space since the Apollo program, and our exploration of space is the most important thing we as humans can do. I am drinking champagne, and fighting back the tears. This is a night I'll remember as long as I live.

Long live Curiosity, and long live curiosity!
Awesome landing! We need a "Curiosity" part pack for KSP asap:)

Deleted

Edited April 24, 2023 by BSOM180

All of this, cost the American tax payer 7.00USD per person...

Money well spent? Yes, money more than well spent on thee single greatest engineering achievement and success in recent history. My daughter will grow up, as we explore the final frontier. It'll be because of this mission, that she'll know that we can Dare to do mighty things, even though why might fail, and still succeed.

Dare Mighty Things!
Stayed up till 3 in the morning watching the Virtual tracker, AND IM ONLY 13, Its kida funny that I love space at this age.

All of this, cost the American tax payer 7.00USD per person...

Money well spent? Yes, money more than well spent on thee single greatest engineering achievement and success in recent history. My daughter will grow up, as we explore the final frontier. It'll be because of this mission, that she'll know that we can Dare to do mighty things, even though why might fail, and still succeed.

Dare Mighty Things!

And barely even remotely a hint of a drop in the bucket compared to the bank bailout.. and honestly, Curiosity is pretty much priceless right now. Dare to do mighty things, indeed.

Its kida funny that I love space at this age.

No, that's quite common...
Well, I'm not getting any sleep tonight! Too much adrenaline! That was AWESOME! Too bad I was too young to appreciate spirit and opportunity landing.
